prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my sister’s boyfriend he’s not “family”?
My sister has been dating this guy for less than three months.  My personal feelings are that he’s an idiot.  I mean he’s young (either late teens or early twenties, idk) so it’s understandable.  I was an idiot back then too.  My problem with him is that he’s made some dangerous choices with my sister involved.  He wrecked his truck with her in it driving drunk.  He also took my sister around this ex felon that everyone in town knows is scary dude just so he could buy some “pot” if it was really pot.  The guy sells a lot more than pot.  He’s definitely not someone I want knowing or getting close with my sister.  

Despite that, it’s her choice who she dates so I’ve kept my opinions to myself until now.  I think he mistook politeness for friendship or something.  He’s shown up at my apartment to hang out.  When I visit my mom’s and he’s there he will basically attache himself to my hip.  Most annoying of all he started calling me brother and fam.  I know those aren’t always specifically referring to actual family, but it’s just what it’s felt like.  

It really got under my skin quickly.  The last time he did it I told him, “You’re not my family.  You’re the guy my sister is dating for now.”   He just said “alright” and I walked away. 

He’s just trying to be friendly and get close with his girlfriend’s family, I understand that.  It felt like it was time for a reality check on our relationship though.  I probably pissed my sister off in the process, I haven’t heard from her since it happened.  



"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

The author's comment could be seen as disrespectful to the boyfriend, even if the author's intentions were protective. The sister might feel that her partner was being criticized without her input, leading to the fallout in their communication.

Also, the boyfriend is trying to get close to the family, which is common in relationships. The author's response might have been a shock to the system, especially if the sister didn't expect her brother to speak out like that. The author might have overstepped by directly addressing the boyfriend instead of talking to his sister first.

But then again, the boyfriend's actions are dangerous. The drunk driving and associating with a known felon are serious issues. The author could be trying to prevent harm to his sister. Even though it's the sister's choice, the author has a right to express concern, especially if the sister is in a vulnerable position.

So, considering all that, the author's actions might be seen as a protective measure, even if it came off as confrontational. The key issue is whether the author had the right to intervene directly. Since the boyfriend's behavior is harmful, the author's intent was to protect his sister, which is a valid concern. However, the method of confrontation might have been inappropriate because it didn't involve the sister first, leading to the sister being upset.

In terms of right or wrong, the author's intentions are good, but the execution might have been flawed. However, the question is whether the author is in the wrong.
